dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, I was just reading this super interesting piece about productivity, you know, specifically between the US and the Eurozone. And, like, the numbers are kind of wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, B, I was just reading this super interesting piece about productivity, you know, specifically between the U S and the Eurozone. And, like, the numbers are kind of wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah? What's the scoop? I mean, I always hear about the US economy, like, doing its own thing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah? What's the scoop? I mean, I always hear about the U S economy, like, doing its own thing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. So, for the past two decades, the US has actually more than *doubled* the Eurozone's productivity growth. And even since the pandemic, um, Europe's up 15%, which sounds good, right? But the US is up over 6%, which, by its *own* historical standards, is actually really strong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. So, for the past two decades, the U S has actually more than doubled the Eurozone's productivity growth. And even since the pandemic, um, Europe's up fifteen percent, which sounds good, right? But the U S is up over six percent, which, by its own historical standards, is actually really strong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whereas eurozone productivity has flat-lined and even fallen slightly since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, like, something's going right over there, and maybe, uh, not so right here, then? What's the initial thought?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, like, something's going right over there, and maybe, uh, not so right here, then? What's the initial thought?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Something seems to be going seriously right in the US and seriously wrong in Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, a lot of people point to the massive fiscal stimulus in the US. You know, all that government spending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, a lot of people point to the massive fiscal stimulus in the U S. You know, all that government spending.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some accounts point to the strong fiscal stimulus applied in the US since the outbreak of the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Right, the big checks. But does that really explain *productivity* though? I mean, I'd think it just ramps up demand, not necessarily how efficient people are.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the big checks. But does that really explain productivity though? I mean, I'd think it just ramps up demand, not necessarily how efficient people are.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But while strong spending stimulus can trigger rapid output and employment growth, it is not clear why it should produce faster productivity growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! The article actually makes that point. Strong spending can mean more jobs, tighter labor markets. Which, ironically, might force companies to hire less productive workers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! The article actually makes that point. Strong spending can mean more jobs, tighter labor markets. Which, ironically, might force companies to hire less productive workers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the contrary, given strong employment growth and tight labor markets, one might expect US companies to be forced to take on less productive workers, with negative implications for output per hour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that makes sense. So, if not stimulus, what then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that makes sense. So, if not stimulus, what then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's more likely, uh, that those tight labor markets are making US firms substitute capital for labor. Think about it: ATMs at banks, QR codes for ordering food even at fancy restaurants.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's more likely, uh, that those tight labor markets are making U S firms substitute capital for labor. Think about it: A T M s at banks, Q R codes for ordering food even at fancy restaurants.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More likely, tight labor markets in the US may mean that firms, unable to find an adequate supply of workers at any price, are impelled to substitute capital for labor to invest in labor-saving technology. Americans visiting a bank branch will encounter plenty of ATMs but sometimes not a single human teller. They are compelled to order meals, even at white-tablecloth restaurants, using a QR code.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I've seen that! Like, you know, you can't even get a human teller sometimes. It's all self-service.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I've seen that! Like, you know, you can't even get a human teller sometimes. It's all self-service.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans visiting a bank branch will encounter plenty of ATMs but sometimes not a single human teller.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And while some Europeans might, uh, be horrified by QR codes at bistros, it's hard to deny those tight labor markets play a role.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And while some Europeans might, uh, be horrified by Q R codes at bistros, it's hard to deny those tight labor markets play a role.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Patrons of Parisian bistros horrified by this thought may argue that a Franco-American cultural difference is at work. But it is hard to deny that tight labor markets also play a role.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, didn't US productivity slow *before* the pandemic? When labor markets weren't so tight?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, didn't U S productivity slow before the pandemic? When labor markets weren't so tight?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recall, however, that US productivity growth had accelerated relative to Europes already in the decade leading up to the pandemic, when labor markets were not so tight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Good point, that's also in there. So, it's not the whole story. And for Europe, it's not just, like, austerity after 2008.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Good point, that's also in there. So, it's not the whole story. And for Europe, it's not just, like, austerity after two thousand eight.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Europe might have been slightly more hell-bent on austerity, but there was not enough difference in demand conditions to explain their different productivity outcomes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So what *is* it for Europe? Strong unions maybe, resisting new tech? Or the EU's regulations? All those data privacy rules, or the new AI rulebook?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So what is it for Europe? Strong unions maybe, resisting new tech? Or the E U's regulations? All those data privacy rules, or the new A I rulebook?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could be that Europes strong trade unions, fearing job destruction, resist their adoption... Alternatively, restrictive European Union rules may be impeding adoption. The EUs data-privacy regulations, and now its proposed AI rulebook, if adhered to strictly, may slow the development of AI applications.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Potentially, yeah. Though Germany has strong unions *and* robot factories. But then there's the big one: Russia and the energy price shock. The US is energy self-sufficient, we aren't.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Potentially, yeah. Though Germany has strong unions and robot factories. But then there's the big one: Russia and the energy price shock. The U S is energy self-sufficient, we aren't.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: although Germany, with a tradition of strong unions, has some of the most robot-intensive factories in the world... Finally, it could simply be that Europe has had bad luck, specifically in the form of Russian President Vladimir Putin and his energy-price shock. The US, being self-sufficient in energy, has not been vulnerable to energy-supply disruptions to the same degree.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Ugh, Putin. That's, uh, a pretty massive external factor. So, Europe's been forced to cut back or restructure costly operations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ugh, Putin. That's, uh, a pretty massive external factor. So, Europe's been forced to cut back or restructure costly operations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: European firms, in contrast, have been forced to suspend their most energy-intensive operations or else to engage in costly restructuring, which is not good for productivity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And that's not good for output per hour.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And that's not good for output per hour.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: costly restructuring, which is not good for productivity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, um, what's the fix then? Is anyone looking at this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, um, what's the fix then? Is anyone looking at this?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Mario Draghi, you know, "Super Mario," is putting together proposals. Things like completing the capital-markets union, removing competition barriers, and better energy efficiency.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mario Draghi, you know, Super Mario, is putting together proposals. Things like completing the capital-markets union, removing competition barriers, and better energy efficiency.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mario Draghi, Europes senior economic statesman, will present the EU with a set of proposals later this year for boosting productivity. No doubt, he will recommend completing Europes capital-markets union so that firms can more easily finance investments in new technologies. Draghi will recommend removing barriers to competition... He will advocate greater energy efficiency and self-sufficiency...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the usual suspects. [interrupts] I feel like I've heard those for years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the usual suspects. I feel like I've heard those for years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Observers like me can confidently predict what Draghi will recommend because such proposals have been around for years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You have! And the article says exactly that. Europe, um, needs to implement these old ideas, but also, like, desperately come up with new ones.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You have! And the article says exactly that. Europe, um, needs to implement these old ideas, but also, like, desperately come up with new ones.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Europe should move now to implement these old ideas. And it desperately needs to come up with new ones.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I guess 'bad luck' only gets you so far.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I guess bad luck only gets you so far.
